awd_titl_txt: Investigating the cognitive mechanisms underlying children's question asking
awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Todd Gureckis and Dr. Marjorie Rhodes at New York University, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist investigating the cognitive mechanisms that enable children to ask effective questions. Question asking is a key tool for learning, especially in childhood, but coming up with an informative question—one that will elicit new and useful information—is often difficult. Studying how children ask informative questions will advance scientific understanding of how humans guide their own learning. This will have implications in educational settings, where students often fail to ask effective questions. Moreover, by understanding how humans guide their own learning, researchers will be better able to desig machines that do the same—an important problem for Artificial Intelligence.

The present project will develop and test a new account of question asking, inspired by recent research on decision making and problem solving. This account delineates multiple routes a learner might take to generate candidate questions and adjudicate between them, with a tradeoff  between the informativeness of the question that is ultimately asked and the computational costs (e.g., time, cognitive effort) associated with generating and selecting this question. Using a multi-method approach, this research will test (1) whether there is evidence for these multiple routes to question asking in 2- to 10-year-old children, and (2) how children navigate the tradeoff between question informativeness and computational cost. In particular, this research will analyze an existing corpus of naturalistic parent-child conversation to test how children’s questions are shaped by their parents’ previous questions and answers, and it will develop new experimental paradigms to investigate how and when children innovate novel, informative questions. The results from this research will shed new light on how parents' questions and answers, children's conceptual knowledge, and computational considerations inform children’s question asking in a range of settings. As a result, this project will take a significant step towards an understanding of the complex cognitive mechanisms that underlie question asking—a skill that exemplifies human intelligence and creativity and makes important contributions to learning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Question asking is a powerful tool for learning, and even young children use questions to seek information. However, prior work has shown that people are sometimes hesitant to ask questions (e.g., in classroom settings), and people's questions are often limited in their potential to reveal information. What are the mechanisms behind question asking that explain humans' early-emerging, yet sometimes limited, question asking capacity? This project aimed to investigate these mechanisms by studying question asking across development. Specifically, the research objectives were to discover (1) how children's question asking is shaped by prior experience with others' questions and answers, (2) how children trade off remembered questions (previously asked by themselves or others) and new questions, and (3) how children's question asking is shaped by conceptual knowledge.

In one line of work, we addressed the first two objectives. Using behavioral experiments and computational modeling, we tested how asking a question in one situation, or being exposed to another person's question in one situation, shapes the questions one asks in future situations. We found that 5- to 10-year-olds and adults frequently re-asked their own and others' prior questions. Even their new questions were similar to prior questions. We also investigated how children decide between remembered questions and new questions. We found that children and adults were especially likely to re-ask another person's question when the question was likely to be helpful (rather than unhelpful) in the present situation. However, there was no evidence that children or adults were more likely to re-ask another person's question when the question had previously received a helpful answer. We have also begun using naturalistic transcripts of parent-child conversation to further investigate how previously received answers shape later questions.

In another line of work, we addressed the third objective. Using behavioral experiments, we tested the hypothesis that children's questions are shaped by "overhypotheses": higher-order beliefs about what kinds of entities have what kinds of properties (for example, the belief that different animal species have different diets). We tested the prediction that children would ask questions about new animal categories by leveraging learned overhypotheses about other animal categories. So far, we have found evidence consistent with this hypothesis: after initial exposure to a new overhypothesis about animals, 4- to 7-year-olds and adults were more likely to ask about the overhypothesis-relevant property when introduced to a new animal category.

Broadly, this project contributed two key insights into the mechanisms underlying question asking. First, this work built novel connections between research on question asking and research on decision making, by viewing question asking as a type of decision problem (deciding what question to ask). This connection generated new hypotheses about the mechanisms underlying question asking, which we began to test in this work. Second, question asking has often been viewed as a domain-general capacity, which can be applied across a diverse range of situations. The work completed under this project demonstrates that question asking is also partly domain-specific, in that it is constrained by domain-specific experience and conceptual knowledge.

This project met its Broader Impact goals by providing training opportunities in research for several undergraduate students; disseminating research findings, data, and materials; and yielding new insights that can inform intervention research aimed at encouraging and enhancing children's question asking in applied settings. This project also provided valuable training opportunities for the PI/postdoctoral fellow.
